text: The snow outside the North Gate has been trampled smooth and bright. Soldiers run back and forth, commands ringing out one after another.
At the edge of the crowd, I spot Alicia. She’s giving deployment orders to several guards—speaking fast, gesturing precisely, like someone doing something she’s done far too many times before.
“Alicia!”
She looks back at me. Her brow barely moves.
“Go back to the inn.”
“I just wanted to make sure you—”
“If you stay here, you’ll only distract Lucia—and the guards.”
“I need them focused on what they’re supposed to do.”
“And you?”
“I’ll hold this position.”
“Turn around and leave. Don’t make me waste time trying to convince you.”
She turns back immediately, continuing to issue orders, as if I’m just another piece of ‘trouble’ she needs cleared from the edge of the battlefield.
I grit my teeth, but I step back anyway. Not because I’m obedient—because I suddenly understand that one more step forward would force her to divide her attention.
On the way back, the town feels like it’s been gripped by an invisible hand around the throat.
Vendors pack up. Windows close. Guards seal off intersections, urging people indoors. Someone tries to ask about the North Gate—no one gives a complete answer.
As I walk, I keep hearing people murmur her name, only to swallow it immediately—as if finishing the sentence would make the ending real.
I return to the inn, slide the bolt into place, and brace a table against the door.

The fire in the hearth burns bright, but the room feels cold, like something essential is missing. The cups are lined up neatly on the counter, yet I can’t shake the feeling that today isn’t really over.
I force myself to stay busy: add firewood, tighten the bolt again, place the short sword where my hand can reach it fastest. I finish once—then I do it again.
Late into the night, sounds drift from the north through the fog—a dull, heavy vibration, like distant walls collapsing. Then comes a long silence, so deep I can hear my own heartbeat.
I stand behind the counter, my palms pressed to the wood, my knuckles whitening.
Near the second half of the night, someone finally passes outside the door. Their footsteps are hurried, carrying snow and exhaustion. A hushed voice says:
“The North Gate held.”
“Did everyone pull back?”
“Don’t ask… just go back.”
I don’t open the door. I don’t chase after them. I simply rest my forehead against the door, my breathing slowly growing heavier.
They never say her name—but I can tell: some people came back. Some didn’t.
I sit behind the counter and stare into the darkness until the sky begins to pale. That night, I don’t sleep even once.
